Elvis isn’t known to have any specific mental illness. There are, however, behaviors which suggest some questionable emotional issues. Elvis experience a great deal of loss in his life: his twin brother, Jesse Garon, the end of his marriage to Priscilla, and the seminal importance of the death of Elvis’ beloved mother, Gladys. There was the loss of a possible career the Colonel stole from him, the impotence he felt stuck in contracts and career tracks, which took him from what he was gravitating to at the peak of his career. When the Beatles visited Graceland one afternoon, Elvis and his guests finally got around to jamming and story swapping. History says the Colonel saw this, didn’t like the draw to the (very free-willed) lads, and about midnight, interrupted the famous meeting , and sent the lads off home. Midnight! They could have jammed all night certainly, he WAS an idol to them. It’s also said Parker allowed no video or audio of the visit. What would that have been like to watch! Elvis seemed from the start to be especially shy, conflict averse, a loner, and potentially suffering a depressive disorder (either parent contributed genetically). Some of these issues could have been responsible for Elvis’ unusual attachment to his mother; she became his world. This topic could require a thesis to justice to. There was a dichotomy to his bond with his mother. (Elvis as a natural blonde, a young boy, with his beloved mother, Gladys)  While she represented all that was good, safe, and reliable in his life, there’s also a good chance Elvis was at least vaguely aware, his mother was a prison for him, the attachment and need to please was so strong. To create a separation in his psyche, Elvis was obsessed with gorgeous teen girls, the literal antithesis of his mother. It’s been noted he could not have intercourse with a woman once she had given birth. Elvis wanted a life that others kept taking from him. Colonel Parker, whom he trusted with his life, was in fact a flimflam man, one who stole Elvis’ talent for personal gain. At some level, I believe Elvis was aware of the dynamics at play. Not crisply so, or seeing the specifics at work, but the vague sense he was always thwarted by someone/something, and could never take control to make his life his own. Later in his career, he longed to do some Rock songs, become a bit more aligned with the later 1960s when the Beatles were in the thick of their creativity. Parker said ‘No’, to that, and Elvis went back to Gospel, Adult Contemporary, and his usual mix including musicals (Elvis hated the films he was contractually tied to). But again, unable to pull strings, make demands, as other artists did, and extricate himself from the course others had chosen for his career. While no formal diagnosis has been made, there is a condition that seems to reflect much of what he struggled with. “Williams syndrome” — a genetic disorder that can bring developmental delays and very mild mental retardation, along with an overly friendly and trusting personality. Remarkably, those diagnosed with Williams Syndrome, experienced a spike in the hormones (associated with love and loving feelings) oxytocin and arginine vasopressin (AVP), when music played. Individuals without this condition saw little or no change in their oxytocin and AVP levels while listening. Interesting! A new study shows that when people with Williams syndrome listen to Elvis’ “Love Me Tender,” to that song or others, they experience more distinct and higher levels of the hormones associated with feelings of love. This is all conjecture based on (1.) the understanding of the Williams Syndrome, and (2.), looking back at Elvis’ life and how this might have been a factor. His reacting to music with loving feelings, and singing those very songs, might have been a remarkable experience, almost a true “high”, for Elvis (and his fans - all reacting to his voice, music, and presence or persona). The love from his audience would have been an exaggerated loving experience. If Elvis could have found the words, at the end he might have mused, ‘What A Long, Dark, Ride It’s Been.’

….thangyaveramuch for requesting an answer from me! as a huuuge elvis fan, i don’t think he had any form of mental illness. first, let me begin with how it fascinates me how icons adjust to all the adoration. there are a rarefied few who have ever even experienced fame on a level that elvis did - without any real road map to follow. the beatles had each other to help cope and were directly influenced and reaping benefits from elvis’ career, yet still made mistakes - lennon was right as, before elvis, there was nothing! perhaps the closest one, p.e. who’s ascendance came close was sinatra, musically, but even his fame didn’t approach elvis-level when you really think about it. i think, on that level, you have a guy like brando where every generation of same era and subsequent actors looked to him as that one figure who defined their lives and careers w/almost sycophantic adoration…how does one cope w/that? post elvis, only muhammad ali had that kind of genre/industry dominance where you are that one and only figure who separates whatever came before from everything that comes after. in reggae, you had marley; in martial arts you had bruce lee, but, still neither on elvis’ level. elvis was the only public figure i know of who was known around the world by his 1st name and never performed outside the country other than a jaunt, or two, to canada in the ‘50s. in addition, elvis was in high school in ‘53, started making his way in ‘54, became a regional buzz in ‘55, and achieved global dominance in ’56 until he died and beyond. as such, who else went from total obscurity to omnipresence in 2 yrs and stayed in the upper echelon of power players? nobody. further, elvis still hold records that may never be broken. some have only recently been broken - the list of his accomplishments and records is way too extensive for me to name in this already lengthy response. finally, how many other acts were chart dominant every year of their career - for elvis some 22 years? i believe he was always one of the top 5 acts from the ’50’s - ‘70’s. now, against this backdrop, add in a young, impressionable, humble, good-natured/-mannered southerner who was patriotic yet rebellious, polished but raw, simple yet complex, spiritual but sensual. elvis had issues, for sure, but who doesn’t? like howard hughes before him, elvis had complexes that would be easily diagnosed and treatable today, so he was ahead of his time, unfortunately. however, none of his idiosyncrasies takes away from his talent, his legacy, or his legend. he is still, for me, the single greatest figure in rock & roll, if not 20th century popular music. now that’s not to say he was more influential than, say, louis armstrong - who i believe was popular music’s closest comparison to abraham in the bible - in that everything ppl are doing today, vocally, performance-wise, and musically can be drawn back generationally to him…but elvis shines above everyone else as far as impact, and is why i consider him the big bang of popular music!

First, I’m not a medical doctor nor clinical psychologist, so I’m going to look at mental illness from a different perspective. It is from the perspective of looking at Elvis as being a universally recognized famous unique individual. Disregard whether or not you’re a fan; whether you loved or hated him. Simply try to imagine that everything that you did, said, thought, etc was open season for the entire world to comment upon. What foods you ate, what clothes you wore, the cars you drove, what you drank, every single thing about you was important to someone. And everyone, everyone wanted to profit in some way from being close to you or knowing something about you. And in Elvis’ case there was Col. Tom Parker who did make money on every single thing Elvis did. Next, imagine that every time you said something, anything, someone was there to try and fix it or take care of it. You’re thirsty? What would you like to drink? Hungry? What would you like to eat? Headache? Aspirin, Tylenol or something stronger? Sounds great! Or does it? As humans, we normally do stuff, and as we get more specialized in the stuff that we do, we hire people to do the lesser stuff. Elvis had people to do all of his stuff except his performances: in studio, on stage or on camera, which were just a couple of hours a day but not that often during the mid- to late-sixties when he was doing mostly movies. I think that may be why he did the Las Vegas thing in the 70’s so he could perform more, and have a purpose; have stuff to do. I think that his mind began to suffer the 60’s when he was doing movies; i.e., when he didn’t have enough stuff to do because everyone would do stuff for him and he wasn’t allowed to do stuff because of his movies contracts. The thing that Elvis did and that only Elvis could do, sing like Elvis, he wasn't doing much of it. Though it’s not like he didn’t do anything at all. He became a black belt in martial arts (Karate?), wanted to join law enforcement and work for Richard Nixon. He wanted to do stuff (kinda crazy stuff), but the world wanted him to perform: movies, TV, songs, stage, etc. And so this was his form of mental illness. He was trapped being Elvis and not being able to do Elvis or do other stuff. His mental illness in the sense I’ve tried to describe was that he wasn’t allowed to be mentally healthy. And ultimately, it was everyone’s desire to please Elvis instead of caring for Elvis that made it worse for him; and therefore, all of us too.

Here’s the thing - Elvis Presley was never diagnosed for any kind of psychological evaluation while he was alive. Any thing we know about him today was done after he was dead. We can speculate, but we really don’t know. Its possible that he suffered from bipolar disorder, which is a more technical name for manic depression. Elvis’ substance abuse, eating disorders, and chronic depression should be placed in the larger context of a personality disorder. What we know about his behavior in the years and months prior to his death is legion, but as to the cause - well, that’s just speculation. As an example, much has been made about the food that he ate. Fried foods, fried meat, even two or three cheeseburgers at a single meal. To many writers of the day that was pretty peculiar and is still commented on all the time - even introspectively - unless you were from the South, as he was. That was pretty common back then. At that time of his life, Mr. Presley was suffering from depression, diabetes and prescription drug abuse. That would be enough for any man and it was a sad way to go.

I don’t think he did; the business that propelled him sky high wasn’t easy to deal with for sure. Always have to be on when you’re on stage, you’re being pulled in many different directions and the need to stay on top is always the wind pushing you on. And the Colonel Parkers of the world, good as he might have been for making Elvis what he became, probably demanded a lot from Elvis. No, I don’t think Elvis was ever mentally ill but the entertainment world was so demanding that it’s easy to succumb to drugs and drink. I don’t excuse him but I understand that he must have wakened in the mornings and said, ‘What happened? Where am I, how did I get here, am I that good, why are all those women screaming at me (me included) and wanting a piece of me?” How do you maintain your sanity in the midst of all of that? To die at such a young age; to never know your child or grandchildren. Success demands a very exorbitant price, doesn’t it, and too often?

What is mental illness? How do you define it? Unless a person has lost mental acuity, it is highly subjective. Do people that commit suicide all suffer from mental illness? I think Elvis suffered from depression - and this depression was the root cause of his drug addiction. Grief causes depression - the loss of self esteem, or the loss of a very close family member (parent, spouse, etc). I have known several people that committed suicide, and the common factor has been grief. Elvis was extraordinarily close to his mother, and her death at a relatively young age, caused a cataclysmic change in his attitude, behavior and perspective. His divorce, years later, compounded an already elevated level of self destruction. No - I do not believe that Elvis was mentally ill, anymore than I believe that Janis Joplin, Jimmy Hendrix, Amy Weinstein or James Morrison (Doors) were mentally ill. They were not retarted - they simply couldn’t deal with their inner-demons.

No, he suffered from addiction. Addiction is a maladaptive behavior or action to (often subconsciously) avoid, dull, or eliminate any painful feeling, memory, or concept in a person’s life. Addiction can mimic closely sometimes a mental disorder because the withdrawals, side affects (of any chemical alteration), cravings, moods, and alteration in behavior to get the addiction are similar. The cycle of addiction can cause an array of erratic emotional responses and behavior as well. This is why mental disorders and addictions are not treated as the same and of many instances fail because of the illiterate and unknowledgeable educational background some practitioners implement in actions towards their patients. Addictions are a deep rooted behavior that is conditioned to ease or eliminate any form of pain which needs to be relearned and mental disorders are derived from a chemical imbalance that needs pharmacological approaches to treat.

Did Elvis Presley suffer from mental illness? We all suffer from different forms of mental illness, some of us just learn to control it better. (Me? Maybe not so much. I kind of like how it works.) The think that Mr. Presley suffered from in the end was drug addiction, obesity, high blood pressure and heart disease. That’s what killed him. His support staff was full of “yes men.” He was seldom told, “No, you shouldn’t/can’t do that.” He could have easily afforded a “keeper” who would look after his well being, but at the time, those kinds of people weren’t a “thing.” (We have a great number of people who could use a “keeper.”) However, I don’t think Presley was anymore mentally ill than any of the rest of us. His condition(s) simply presented in a different way.

Elvis was the first human to reach such a superstar status on the planet, he was called “The King.” His genre-bending and rough sound catalyzed the movement known as rock n’ roll.  Did Elvis Presley suffer from mental illness? Possible, as he was never psychologically diagnosed while alive. Truth is, Elvis never really felt comfortable in his skin, unless he was on stage. He found himself in the middle of an issue many of us find ourselves in: living an outer life that doesn’t match what’s going on inside. This creates an anxious tendency to cling to an ever-elusive image. It creates an issue that many didn’t even know existed at that time: anxiety. There is no public record that Elvis was ever officially diagnosed with a mental health disorder. Growing up as he did in the rural south, it is likely he would have viewed seeking treatment for depression or anxiety as a sign of weakness. Based on what we know about his life, his attachment to his mother, the loss of his twin, being something of an outsider as a youth, his being thrust into the spotlight at an early age, those certainly can be factors that drive mental health challenges. His impulsive behavior, addiction, difficulty in maintaining lasting relationships can be signs of someone who is struggling with a psychological disorder. We will never know the answer for sure, but it’s likely.
